summary_points: 1. Ameren Illinois Company issued $350 million in 5.625% First Mortgage Bonds due 2055 on March 3, 2025, receiving net proceeds of approximately $346.9 million before expenses.
2.  The bonds were offered pursuant to a registration statement that became effective October 13, 2023, and a prospectus supplement dated February 24, 2025.
3. The offering involved several underwriters, with BNY Mellon Capital Markets, LLC, BofA Securities, Inc., Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, and Truist Securities, Inc. acting as representatives.
1. Paul Thomas, Willis Towers Watson's Non-Executive Chair, will retire at the end of his current term (May 2025) and will not seek re-election, replaced by Paul Reilly, effective after the 2025 AGM.
2.  Paul Reilly, appointed as the new Non-Executive Chair, has extensive experience in global financial and professional services, having served as CEO of Raymond James Financial until 2025.
3. This 8-K filing reports the departure of a director and the appointment of a successor; no other significant financial or operational changes are noted.
1. Xylem's 2024 revenue increased 16.3% year-over-year to $8.562 billion, driven by acquisitions and organic growth, but management anticipates only up to a 2% revenue increase in 2025.
2.  Xylem incurred $49 million in restructuring charges in 2024 and anticipates an additional $90 million to $110 million in 2025, aiming for savings of $75 million to $95 million.
3. Xylem faces a potential $76 million liability from a pending tax case in Sweden.
1. Progressive's investment portfolio grew significantly in 2024, increasing by $14.25 billion to $80.25 billion.
2.  Progressive's new personal auto product (model 8.9) showed favorable initial results in 17 states by December 31, 2024.
3.  Progressive faces potential material harm from class action lawsuits in nine states alleging improper valuation of total loss vehicle claims.
1. Hesam Hosseini was appointed Chief Operating Officer of Match Group, Inc., effective April 1, 2025, in addition to his current role as CEO of Evergreen & Emerging Brands.
2.  Gary Swidler resigned as President of Match Group, Inc., effective April 1, 2025, but will remain as an employee advisor until July 4, 2025.

3.  Mr. Hosseini's new employment agreement includes an annual base salary of $635,000 and a target annual bonus of 150% of his base salary, along with equity awards and benefits, and includes non-compete and non-solicitation clauses for the term of employment and 12 months thereafter.
1. Bank of New York Mellon Corp announced a proposed public offering of depositary shares representing a 1/100th interest in its Series J Non-Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock on March 3, 2025.

2. The net proceeds from this offering, if completed, are intended for general corporate purposes, potentially including the redemption of some or all of the company's Series G Non-Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock in September 2025.
3.  The success of the offering and the redemption of the Series G Preferred Stock are contingent upon market conditions and other factors, with no guarantee of either occurring.

1. On February 28, 2025, Las Vegas Sands Corp.'s subsidiary, Marina Bay Sands Pte. Ltd., terminated its existing credit facility agreement (originally dated June 25, 2012), fully repaying all outstanding loans and cancelling all commitments.
2.  The filing is an 8-K Current Report, indicating a material event occurred.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned in this section of the filing.
1. John Griffin, Hologic Inc.'s General Counsel, will retire on May 1, 2025, transitioning to a Special Advisor role.
2.  Anne Liddy will become Hologic Inc.'s General Counsel on May 1, 2025.

3.  As of May 1, 2025, Mr. Griffin will lose eligibility for additional equity awards and matching contributions under Hologic Inc.'s Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation Plan, but will retain his base salary and eligibility for an incentive bonus.
1. On March 3, 2025, UPS appointed Kevin P. Clark, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Aptiv PLC, to its Board of Directors, expanding the board to thirteen members.
2. UPS's 2024 revenue was $91.1 billion.

3. Mr. Clark's compensation will be in accordance with UPS's director compensation practices, as described in its 2024 proxy statement, and he is expected to join the board’s Audit Committee following the 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareowners.
1. Humana Inc. reaffirmed its FY 2025 guidance of approximately $15.88 in diluted GAAP earnings per share and approximately $16.25 in adjusted diluted earnings per share on March 3, 2025.

2.  The company's adjusted EPS guidance is $0.37 higher than its GAAP EPS guidance, reflecting $0.49 in amortization of identifiable intangibles and a -$0.12 cumulative net tax impact of non-GAAP adjustments.
3.  The filing includes forward-looking statements, which are subject to various risks and uncertainties detailed in the company's SEC filings.
1. Kroger's CEO, Rodney McMullen, resigned on March 3, 2025, following an investigation into personal conduct unrelated to company performance.

2.  For the full year 2024, Kroger expects identical sales (without fuel) to be at the high end of its guidance range and adjusted earnings per share to be slightly above the high end of its guidance range.
3. Ronald Sargent, the current Lead Director, was appointed interim CEO and Chairman, with a national search firm engaged to find a permanent replacement.
1. As of February 28, 2025, News Corp had repurchased approximately US$642,827,284.89 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2.  On March 3, 2025, News Corp reported repurchasing 21,106,263 Class A shares and 10,413,421 Class B shares on February 28, 2025.

3. News Corp’s stock repurchase program, authorized to acquire up to $1 billion of outstanding shares,  intends to continue repurchasing Class A and B common stock from time to time, subject to market conditions.

1. Microchip Technology Inc. announced on March 3, 2025, additional restructuring actions resulting in approximately 2,000 job cuts and estimated restructuring costs between $30 million and $40 million.
2.  The Tempe, Arizona wafer fabrication facility (Fab 2) closure, initially projected for later in 2025, is now expected to be completed by May 2025.
3. These restructuring actions are anticipated to reduce Microchip's annual operating expenses by $90 million to $100 million once fully implemented by the end of June 2025.

1. Ameren Missouri reached a preliminary agreement on February 26, 2025, to resolve all revenue requirement issues related to its June 2024 electric service rate review with the Missouri Public Service Commission (MoPSC).
2. A MoPSC decision on the rate review is anticipated by May 2025, with new rates potentially effective by June 2025.
3.  The MoPSC's approval of the agreement, and the absence of any subsequent rehearing applications or appeals, are uncertain.
